isis.stitle: PROPELLER SHAFT - VIBRATION - CHECKING PROPELLER SHAFT RUNOUT (PROPELLER SHAFT INSTALLED)

svcproc.title: CHECKING PROPELLER SHAFT RUNOUT (PROPELLER SHAFT INSTALLED)
svcproc.para: Excessive companion flange, yoke, and/or propeller shaft runout can create or influence vibration.
Runout checks can be taken with the propeller shaft in the vehicle.

step1.para: Block the wheels (including the front wheels).
Remove the axle shafts or place jack stands under the axles to raise all of the rear wheels off the ground.
Rotate the propeller shaft by hand and read measured runout.

svcproc.para: Radial runout of the installed propeller shaft must not exceed .010I (0.254 mm) T.I.R. over the runout specification shown in Figure 35 . Measurements are taken 3 inches (76.2 mm) from the tube ends and in the center of the tube. Be sure to clean surfaces where dial indicator readings are taken.

The companion flange mounting nuts and the bolts that attach the propeller shaft to the flange must be tight to assure driveline balance. The least amount of looseness in the flange mounting nuts or the shaft attaching bolts is enough to cause excessive vibration at high propeller shaft speeds. Refer to the TORQUE CHART
for the proper torque specifications.
Although it is rare, a distorted yoke can cause vibration. If you know the propeller shaft is straight and balanced, check yoke runout with a dial indicator.
